text: I'll roll tape here for a second. Darrel, I'm gonna be throwing you a signal tape-delayed, so you can check what it sounds like on the tape. Okay, you're now tape-delayed. What does it sound like? Yeah. Okay, now you should be just gettin' one voice. Two voices. Hold on. Okay, now you should be just getting one voice. Still two voices? Oh, I don't know what it is. Hang on. Ok now you're getting one voice. Ok. Joe say hello to Daryl. Hello Daryl. Are you anywhere? What did you sound like Daryl? Sounds good? Ok. Switching back to standard. Alrighty. We're ready to go on this end. And are you okay? You said on that end? Yeah. Okay. I read the forward in The Study of War No More again last night. So some of this stuff is things you've already talked about and other things. But a lot of people who listen to the show probably, if they read books, they don't read forward. Yeah. OK, this is my first question. OK. Oh, yeah. Some of the questions will not be exactly a question. I'll just make a statement, and then you can respond to it, like this first one. Your writing started out as a hobby that developed into a profession, didn't it? Well yeah, although the development was fairly rampant. I always wrote ever since I was in second or third grade. I wrote a lot of poetry. When I was a senior in college, my last semester, I took a creative writing course. I was in physics and astronomy, but I wanted to take something easy to fill out my 18 hours or so. I wrote two science fiction stories. Eventually, I sold both of them. I was drafted and then when I came back from Vietnam they give you 30 days leave and I just retyped the stories then and sent them out and one of them sold before I was out of the army. Then I don't know I just uh... I never thought you could make very much money at it but I saw it as sort of a source of beer money. And when I decided to drop out of graduate school and try a semester of writing full time I sold my first novel about a couple of days after I dropped out so I never went back. That would tend to kind of cement things. Yeah. Yeah, it's funny. Coincidence has a lot to do with it. There's an awful lot of luck in getting started writing. Yeah. Your first works had to do with war. You were in Vietnam and that must have had a significant impact on you. Oh yeah. Yeah, well it's uh, of course, it's the most dramatic thing that's ever happened to me so it's the most obvious, uh, fuel for my fiction. Although I don't want to be typed as a writer about war. I have written two novels and edited one anthology about it. Yeah. Yeah. The old adage, to write what you know, and of the things I know, that's the one that's most, uh, universally interesting. Okay, yeah, a couple of the following questions have to do with war and some of the themes you have in some of your books and stories. Okay, here they come. Okay. In Infinite Dreams, which is a collection of stories you published in various publications since about 1972, war and violence linked with a change in mankind's behavior seem to be recurrent themes in some of these stories. Are you saying that sometimes man has to face violent conflicts in order to change his behavior? Well, I don't think I'm coming out and saying it that directly. I think it's obvious that confronting death on a daily basis changes people and sometimes radically for the worse than people who are totally dehumanized by war. But speaking racially, I don't think you could make such a broad statement. what's behind some of the things I'm writing is the hope that human nature eventually may improve to the point where we won't have wars find other ways to settle our differences Yeah Let me skip up that I got another question that has to deal with that let me find it here well Dave is trying to find his question that he just wrote down about half an hour ago maybe I missed that one when I was transcribing it to type written material yeah I'm actually good being in the Army was so that important effect on my writing aside from war because I met a whole new class of people. That is, all of my friends, while I was growing up, tended to be white middle-class, upper-middle-class kids, and their successors. White middle-class, upper-class scientists, and so forth. And it was just a mundane revelation to find that people who came from different backgrounds still had an awful lot in common with me. As most of The guys in my combat outfit were urban black high school or junior high school dropouts. They got along quite well. Yeah, I found the question. Okay. In both your novels, Mind Bridge and Forever War, you have mankind united in the face of a crisis with an alien race. Do you think that we'll ever be able to progress without this sort of conflict spurring it on? I wonder whether, well, of course, it's a simplification, and it's an old theme in science fiction. That is everybody getting together because the Martians are after us. I wish I could say that I thought that we would be able to do this in the face of a less dramatic uniform enemy. That is, obviously, the combined threats of overpopulation, and dwindling resources, and industrial pollution, are as threatening as either of the enemies in those two novels. But we can't make a coherent face against this enemy and fight it. It's a way of making specific a sort of a real but diffuse nightmare, some of your stories that do deal with war and conflict on a personal level there's a story where a man is hit by a laser mine and his leg is cut off he's hurt personally family, does that relate to something in your own experiences? I was wounded pretty severely in Vietnam. I was hospitalized for 6 months. And it was a booby trap. I didn't set it off, somebody else did, but it was a pretty big one. And I had over 200 separate wounds. But managed to come out of it alright after a few months of physical therapy. so it's uh yeah i draw on that experience uh the one you're talking about is a mind of his own but i think i've got other uh short stories like the private war of private jacob that draw on that memory yeah are you exercising demons pardon are you exercising some demons i don't uh i don't know whether i am or not i think i'm just using available material will. I don't think the demon is too easily exercised by fiction. That's a truism that I don't think is always true. Yeah. In your first novel, Forever War, it's a novel that deals with war on an intergalactic or in a galactic level. It's similar in some respects to Heinlein's Starship Troopers. Did you intentionally write it as sort of an answer to that or has it just come about that the work ended up that way? Well, there was no intention on my part. In fact, I didn't realize until I was about 70 or 80 pages into the book that many of the details were similar to Starship Troopers. Somebody else pointed that out when he read the manuscript. I wasn't doing an answer to Heinlein's book. I thought Heinlein's book was admirable in many ways, even though we have diametrically opposed philosophies. But if there's any relation to any book, it is to my own first novel, War Year, because it's an expansion into a science fiction universe of the notions that I was trying to express in mainstream novel. Yeah, that was... ...incidentally, wrote me a nice postcard after the Forevermore won the Hugo, pointing out that we do have certain things in common that most reviewers didn't see. Dislike for the draft being one of them. Yeah, I've heard he's a very interesting man. Yeah. Also, in Forever Warrior you deal with time compression on the starships. They travel off to battle at speeds near to that of light, and then when they return, hundreds of years have passed on the Earth. That's hard science. Yeah. Many writers, if they're considered hard science or soft science, and some mix the two styles together, what part does hard science play in your writing? Well, I try to use it to make the worlds that are in an event more beliefful. At least to me, since I do have a background in science and engineering, I think— well, the writer has to at least suspend his own disbelief while he's making up these stories. It's easier for me to do it at a fairly solid scientific foundation. Even though my science is rather old-fashioned to probably rather sloppy by a real scientist's standards. It's still enough to convince me, so it's fulfilled its function. For instance, it goes deeper than just description, the time dilation in the forever war. Though it's scientifically accurate, its main function is metaphorical. and that is to demonstrate how the soldiers who fight a war become isolated from the culture that they're supposed to be protecting. Just using a science fictional device to exaggerate something that happens to every soldier. Yeah, and that when these soldiers leave and come back, the world they left is in even the same world once they get back to it. Which is quite true. I remember when I came back from Vietnam, I was suddenly plunged into what was an alien culture, even though I'd only been a soldier for two years. A lot of things had changed. You know, it's not a great thing to come back. There were no victory parades and that sort of thing. Yeah. I can empathize with that. Yeah. The conflicts aside, Forever War and Mind Bridge have optimistic endings. But in your novel, All My Sins Remembered, was that put together from a series of short stories? About half of it appeared as two novelettes, you know. Yeah. But in the end of it, the protagonist is just literally turned off and killed at the end of it. It's a rather pessimistic ending. Well, it was planned all along that way. The story is about a bureaucracy that totally takes over a man's identity, and he doesn't really exist except as a tool for that bureaucracy. When he becomes an efficient tool, he's scrapped. Yeah, he's programmed to go out and do certain, I guess what you'd call covert operations. Yeah. and he does them more or less against his will that is to say through very advanced techniques of conditioning he's turned into a thoroughly different person he was a Buddhist a pacifist when he started out he did not get the job he signed up for they twisted him around into being a killing machine and at the end of it he what rebelled against that yeah finally man, he was no longer suited their purpose and then they got rid of him. Right. Yeah. Uh, uh, jumping up to MIND BBRIDGE, um, it's dedicated to your teachers at the Iowa Writers Workshop. Right. And the style of the novel is unusual. Is there a connection with that? Oh, not really. The connection is with John Dos Paussos, actually. I read the USA Trilogy some years before I wrote Mind Bridge and really was impressed by the way it worked and thought it would work really well in science fiction. So I tried it out in a rather long short story to Howard Hughes, A Modest Proposal. And it looked like it would work, so I went ahead and applied it to Mind Bridge. I did do most of that book while I was studying at Iowa, That's why it's a dedication. You also used some humor to Howard Hughes' Amada's proposal. Do you find that a useful tool to get across your message? Yeah. Sarcasm is the operative word. I think even in a deadly serious book there has to be some leavening of humor. A lot of science fiction is just too somber and full of message. I think my primary function is to be an entertainer. Humor is part of that. I also noticed in the dedication, a lot of the authors at the workshop were mainstream authors. What was their reaction to science fiction? Well, they were a little apprehensive about it. See, they didn't know I was a science fiction writer when I joined the workshop. So I joined on the basis of my first novel, which was not science fiction. And some of them were outwardly hostile towards science fiction, such as Stanley Elkham. Others were anywhere between apprehensive and slightly sympathetic. Yeah. Yeah. But they couldn't ignore the fact that I was making more money than most of them were with my science fiction. and that might have been a cause of tension in some cases. Yeah, that's a point that's kind of hard to argue with. Yeah. Yeah, that attitude is one I've never really been able to understand because some of our greatest novels are science fiction novels. Well, that's true. But the field is judged by its worst, not by its best. And people like that think of science fiction, they think in terms of grade B movies and lousy television. They have never read much of that best of the field. It's a pity. That's true. Back again to the Mine Bridge, a specific question about it. The alien race that created the Mine Bridge, you suggest they commit racial suicide. Why do you think a supposedly advanced race would do something like that? I don't know. I was feeling, well, they've lived for millions or hundreds of millions or even billions of years thoroughly, individually immortal, and there just wasn't anything else that they hadn't done, except died. But that's sort of a throw away. I didn't put any deep thought into why they should do that. I just wanted the image of the light from their passing, lighting up the Knights of the Earth while humans were just meandered gone. They supernova-ed this star. The Cygnus loop is the remains of the civilization. Yeah. I may be wrong here in this next question so correct me if I am. In Tri-Centennial, when the starship returns to Earth all of the humans are gone, Yeah, it never returns actually. It doesn't return, okay. That is a shift in view point. Oh, okay, what happened to the humans on the Earth? Some sort of a war, I assume. Okay. The um, it doesn't say anything except that there's no life left on Earth and it looks pretty much like an ecological zero, it's just a void And my other question about Trostantino is who were the beings in the glass and metal tubes? Oh, those are the leftovers, the people who were on the L5 type colony, they're still there Their society is a closed-cycle agriculture society, and there's no reason that they would have to die when the earth died. Uh-huh, okay. Yeah. In various novels and stories that you've written, you've created some excellent aliens. How do you go about constructing your aliens? Not very logically. I've been asked that before, and it's a hard thing to answer. I know, for instance, the LeVrye in Mind Bridge. I did have this notion of aliens who were shape changers, who appeared as angelically beautiful creatures, but were ferocious killers, mindless killers. I wanted that image. But normally, I don't know the Sikang and All My Sons Remembered. I just thought I'd make a big bug that had a Jewish sense of humor. Everything else is decoration. You sort of close your eyes and see this critter and type it down. I have on occasion looked through books of animal anatomy and just glanced through biology and botany textbooks to try to be inspired by natural forms, but I don't have any algorithm that I know works for making monsters. In MindBridge and Forever War, humanity has greatly changed at the end of both books, almost an evolutionary difference. do you believe that we will have radically different natures in the future? I think it's quite possible even say within the span of a century so many of the things that determine human nature are things that can be mitigated by technology such as the problem of dying so soon that is it's possible that we'll in a couple of generations to be able to live a century, two centuries, maybe a thousand years maybe as long as you care to that will radically change human nature because it will take the pressure off of individuals there are other less so sanguine notions it's possible that the sciences of communication will grow into a kind of sophisticated mind control where it will be difficult for the individual to know exactly what is his idea and what has been induced by his own society. Sort of a sophisticated, lifelong brainwashing. It doesn't seem too unlikely. If you can argue that it's happening now. Similar to what Colonel Luther Pohl did in Space Merchants. Right. is Space Merchants' chillingly prophetic novel, actually. They do a lot of things with our heads. Those of us who stay away from the TV screen aren't as affected by others, but it is there. Yeah. Out of the novels and short stories that you've written, which one did you enjoy writing the most? Let me see. Strangely enough, I think I enjoyed most writing a pseudonymous adventure novel called Antar's Revenge because it was so easy. Most of my writing was very difficult to do. And this was just setting a spy up and letting him knock the bad guys down and win in the end is all very pleasant in terms of more serious work I think Mind Bridge was the most fun to ride I had the most latitude there I also enjoyed that the most until this latest one worlds yeah I read Atar the Merman oh god I guess it was couple years back. When did you write that? I guess about 1971. I didn't even know it was you. That one I got captured by the cover. But that appeared to be the beginning of a series. Yes, that's right. The idea was I was going to write three or four and then somebody else is going to pick it up. That's why it's not under my name. It's what they call a house name. And I got tired of the damn thing after two. I did write a third one and got paid for it, but it's pretty lousy and they didn't print it. And then the whole series just fizzled away. I guess they were working on a contemporary enthusiasm over dolphins. and when that started evaporating, they put the kibosh on the series. Or maybe they couldn't find anybody to continue it. Yeah, I would imagine writing a series book like that would be difficult. Well, the first one's easy. And in the case of Antar, the second one was pretty easy, too. But I've also done two Star Trek novels, which are sort of series. It gets old real fast. You can't make up things. You have to be consistent with the canon that you've already established. And that can get real boring after about 100,000 words. Tiresome. Yeah, and the Star Trek material that you've written, the framework is already built, and you have to build a story around the framework. Yeah, it's already established. That was sort of cute though – writing the first one I had fun because I'd been in service during most of Star Trek. So I had to treat it as a research project and I went and saw the TV show every afternoon, and then I read all the books and made charts and things like that and sat down and wrote the books. That was an odd thing, I had to sign a two-bump contract. And whereas I found the first one very interesting and fun to write, the second one was quite difficult to write. And the first one took three months, and the second took nine. How did you get approached to write those? Well, it was just being in the right place at the right time. In a way, you know, Jim Blish was doing the series of these things, and I knew they were quite financially successful. and when Jim died I was in correspondence with Fred Poe who was his editor there and I just you know apologized for being like a vulture circling over the corpse but asked whether anybody was picking up Jim's work and he said why don't you give it a try and actually well Jim was taking the scripts from the TV show and just turning them into short stories, whereas they wanted me to do what Jim would have done if he had lived, which was write original novels around the Star Trek characters. One of the novels was Planet of Destruction. Excuse me, Planet of Judgment. Excuse me. Let's see. I read one of them and that was one that had to do where they discovered I guess what would be sort of considered a Dyson sphere yeah is that Planet of Judgment or is that the other one World Without End World Without End I could not find that book tore my library up trying to find it oh I like doing the technical part of that it's not a Dyson sphere well it is a hollowed out asteroid Bernal sphere There isn't a proper name for it. But I tried to work out this alien science. I've got a notebook full of stuff about how flying aliens would build their cities. Isn't that part was fun enough. I had to abuse myself somehow. Off the cuff question here. Um, anybody ever consider them for possible Star Trek episodes? Well, unfortunately, I have no say in that. They can, they're quite free to take them without asking me or paying me. It's part of the contract at Paramount. Oh, how wonderful at Paramount. Yeah. Uh, okay. Um, uh, as to your writing itself, How do you go about constructing your novels? Do you come up with an idea for the novel or characters and then work them into a particular setting or what? Well, the most consistent pattern they have is working out the actual structure, the way time is handled in the novel. It sounds rather dry, but I don't like to outline the story in any detail because then there are no surprises. So I start out with the structure, how the viewpoint is handled and so forth, and start working and modify the structure as the story builds. Usually I have some vague idea of how it's going to end that becomes less vague as the novel progresses. In short stories I normally start with a character who seems interesting and make him do something. ... in other words you set up sort of a lettuce work and then you let the story build itself on that. Yeah. That seems to work better for me. Although often the structure does have to be modified halfway through. I don't you know want to fit into a Procrastean bed by it. Yeah, um, Okay. I wanna ask some questions about worlds, but this is going to be a neat trick, see, because I haven't rid it yet. Yeah, from Viking. From Viking and hardcover. You got a paper contract out on it yet? You've had pretty good luck with going from hardcover to paper, haven't you? Yeah, so far I have. The reason for doing it is to maintain a high level of critical attention for the books. These books that are sold as paperback originals don't get reviewed in the right places. Because you do get more money up front, of course, doing a paperback deal. But it seems to have worked in my case to go with the traditional route. Yeah. let's go ahead and keep tape rolling what is briefly just real briefly what is worlds about it's the first part of a first part of a trilogy yeah what is what's happening in Joel Haldeman's world in worlds well it starts out about a century from now and it's essentially the story of a woman who grew up, was born and grew up on a space colony a space settlement and is sent to Earth for a year of post-graduate work or finishing if you want to call it that being set up for a political position as a liaison between this world and Earth and various strange things happen to her in the year that she's here It's sort of a old heldong so a mad kind of a novel. She grows by being sort of bounced around by Earth. And the second novel, Stars, takes over where the first one ends and takes her into old age. Will all three novels be following this one character? No, she dies in the second one. I think. I haven't finished the second one. That's an interesting way of writing. You discover it as you write it. Yeah it's best for me. Some people have to outline very meticulously. But when I do that I lose interest in it. Yeah you already know it's going to happen. Yeah just type it. Right. What did... come on Dave, phrase the question. What made you decide to put together a trilogy rather than just like one novel? Well, it seems like an awfully big thing to put into one book. And it looks as if each one of the trilogy, each volume of the trilogy, will be longer than any other book I've ever written. By at least a third in each one. So indeed, it would have been a book nearly a half million words long. It's rather difficult to sell. and I just, you know, everybody's doing trilogies, so I can't, I do a trilogy, too, as part of it. They're very successful. The second and third books have a built-in audience. Also, I wanted to try something big. Half a million words is pretty big. Yeah. I was stifling laughs there when you were talking about everybody who's written trilogies. Lots of science fiction trilogies, too. Yeah. It's almost a sub-genre, actually. And now there are four and five books, actually. Gene Wolfe's Torture series. The lead is going to be five volumes. no end to it. Of course there's a Farm Reserver Boat series that just goes on and on and on. Do you imagine in this trilogy you will have constructed sort of a future history? Yeah it turns out that way. Do you think you might follow it up with later novels or is that just further on down the line? No, the third volume, Gods, covers about a million years, I think. So there's not much point in thinking about a fourth one. In other words, you take it far into the future? Yeah. Okay. I wanted to try a Stapeldonian kind of novel. It'll be the most difficult one, I think. Taking it that far into the future, the possibilities are just about limitless. Yeah. And it will probably be optimistic. The first book is not too optimistic, it's a dystopian kind of thing. Jack Williamson says that, uh, most science fiction works, in fact, most mainstream things are divided between either utopian or dystopian viewpoints. Well, the point is neither one is mutually exclusive. It's possible to have a complex enough vision of the future that we can see alternation, utopia and dystopia. That's another good thing about having a scoped canvas of a trilogy. Yeah, it would allow you to cover a lot of areas. Yeah. and I can run what I'm doing both the first and the second is describing two cultures being able to switch from chapter to chapter and use one to illuminate the other and in fact one is a utopia and one is a dystopia okay I've covered all my questions that I have down here plus a couple I made up as I went along Darrell is there anything that you would like Do you have any authors that you really enjoy reading, science fiction in particular? Well it varies a lot. I guess Gene Wolfe is my favorite writer right now. I like Roger Salinowski very much. Actually I'm reading The Number of the Beast right now. Heimline as an old favorite but I've not been too happy about his later books the number the beast is turning out to be rather more entertaining than I thought it would be let me see I like Silverberg and Lee Quinn and quite a bit of Chip Delaney Samuel Delaney so Fred Pohl Fred Pohl is doing marvelous work The problem is I don't read too much science fiction. I read something after 16 people have raved about it. And I finally go pick it up. Or 16 people hated it. And I want to find out why. Good reasons for both. Wow. Yeah, that covers about what we wanted to do. Any loose ends on your end? No, no. Oh, I can't believe it. Okay, we're shutting down the tape. Oh, I don't know.

Darrel, I'm gonna be throwing you a signal tape-delayed, so you can check what it sounds
like on the tape.
Okay, you're now tape-delayed.
What does it sound like?
Yeah.
Okay, now you should be just gettin' one voice.
Two voices.
Hold on.
Okay, now you should be just getting one voice.
Still two voices?
Oh, I don't know what it is.
Hang on.
Ok now you're getting one voice.
Ok.
Joe say hello to Daryl.
Hello Daryl.
Are you anywhere?
What did you sound like Daryl?
Sounds good?
Ok. Switching back to standard.
Alrighty.
We're ready to go on this end.
And are you okay? You said on that end?
Yeah.
Okay.
I read the forward in The Study of War No More again last night.
So some of this stuff is things you've already talked about and other things.
But a lot of people who listen to the show probably,
if they read books, they don't read forward.
Yeah.
OK, this is my first question.
OK.
Oh, yeah.
Some of the questions will not be exactly a question.
I'll just make a statement, and then you can respond to it, like this first one.
Your writing started out as a hobby that developed into a profession, didn't it?
Well yeah, although the development was fairly rampant.
I always wrote ever since I was in second or third grade.
I wrote a lot of poetry.
When I was a senior in college, my last semester,
I took a creative writing course.
I was in physics and astronomy,
but I wanted to take something easy to fill out my 18 hours or so.
I wrote two science fiction stories.
Eventually, I sold both of them.
I was drafted and then when I came back from Vietnam they give you 30 days leave
and I just retyped the stories then and sent them out and one of them sold before I was out of the army.
Then I don't know I just uh...
I never thought you could make very much money at it but I saw it as sort of a source of beer money.
And when I decided to drop out of graduate school and try a semester of writing full time
I sold my first novel about a couple of days after I dropped out so I never went back.
That would tend to kind of cement things.
Yeah.
Yeah, it's funny.
Coincidence has a lot to do with it.
There's an awful lot of luck in getting started writing.
Yeah.
Your first works had to do with war.
You were in Vietnam and that must have had a significant impact on you.
Oh yeah.
Yeah, well it's uh, of course, it's the most dramatic thing that's ever happened to me
so it's the most obvious, uh, fuel for my fiction.
Although I don't want to be typed as a writer about war.
I have written two novels and edited one anthology about it.
Yeah.
Yeah.
The old adage, to write what you know, and of the things I know, that's the one that's most, uh,
universally interesting.
Okay, yeah, a couple of the following questions have to do with war and some of the themes you have in some of your books and stories.
Okay, here they come.
Okay.
In Infinite Dreams, which is a collection of stories you published in various publications since about 1972,
war and violence linked with a change in mankind's behavior seem to be recurrent themes in some of these stories.
Are you saying that sometimes man has to face violent conflicts in order to change his behavior?
Well, I don't think I'm coming out and saying it that directly.
I think it's obvious that confronting death on a daily basis changes people and sometimes
radically for the worse than people who are totally dehumanized by war.
But speaking racially, I don't think you could make such a broad statement.
what's behind some of the things I'm writing is the hope that human nature
eventually may improve to the point where we won't have wars
find other ways to settle our differences
Yeah
Let me skip up that
I got another question that has to deal with that
let me find it here well Dave is trying
to find his question that he just wrote
down about half an hour ago maybe I missed that one when I was transcribing
it to type written material yeah I'm actually good being in the Army was so
that important effect on my writing aside from war because I met a whole
new class of people. That is, all of my friends, while I was growing up, tended to be white
middle-class, upper-middle-class kids, and their successors. White middle-class, upper-class
scientists, and so forth. And it was just a mundane revelation to find that people who
came from different backgrounds still had an awful lot in common with me. As most of
The guys in my combat outfit were urban black high school or junior high school dropouts.
They got along quite well.
Yeah, I found the question.
Okay.
In both your novels, Mind Bridge and Forever War,
you have mankind united in the face of a crisis with an alien race.
Do you think that we'll ever be able to progress without this sort of conflict spurring it on?
I wonder whether, well, of course, it's a simplification, and it's an old theme in science fiction.
That is everybody getting together because the Martians are after us.
I wish I could say that I thought that we would be able to do this in the face of a less dramatic uniform enemy.
That is, obviously, the combined threats of overpopulation,
and dwindling resources, and industrial pollution,
are as threatening as either of the enemies in those two novels.
But we can't make a coherent face against this enemy and fight it.
It's a way of making specific a sort of a real but diffuse nightmare,
some of your stories
that do deal with war
and conflict
on a personal level
there's a story
where a man is
hit by a laser mine
and his
leg is
cut off
he's hurt personally
family, does that relate to something in your own experiences?
I was wounded pretty severely in Vietnam.
I was hospitalized for 6 months.
And it was a booby trap.
I didn't set it off, somebody else did, but it was a pretty big one.
And I had over 200 separate wounds.
But managed to come out of it alright after a few months of physical therapy.
so it's uh yeah i draw on that experience uh the one you're talking about is a mind of his own
but i think i've got other uh short stories like the private war of private jacob
that draw on that memory yeah are you exercising demons pardon are you exercising some demons
i don't uh i don't know whether i am or not i think i'm just using available material
will. I don't think the demon is too easily exercised by fiction. That's a truism that
I don't think is always true.
Yeah. In your first novel, Forever War, it's a novel that deals with war on an intergalactic
or in a galactic level.
It's similar in some respects
to Heinlein's
Starship Troopers.
Did you
intentionally write it
as sort of an answer to that
or has it just come about
that the work ended up that way?
Well, there was no
intention on my part.
In fact, I didn't realize
until I was about 70 or 80 pages
into the book
that many of the details were similar to Starship Troopers.
Somebody else pointed that out when he read the manuscript.
I wasn't doing an answer to Heinlein's book.
I thought Heinlein's book was admirable in many ways,
even though we have diametrically opposed philosophies.
But if there's any relation to any book,
it is to my own first novel, War Year,
because it's an expansion into a science fiction universe of the notions that I was trying to express in mainstream novel.
Yeah, that was...
...incidentally, wrote me a nice postcard after the Forevermore won the Hugo,
pointing out that we do have certain things in common that most reviewers didn't see.
Dislike for the draft being one of them.
Yeah, I've heard he's a very interesting man.
Yeah.
Also, in Forever Warrior you deal with time compression on the starships.
They travel off to battle at speeds near to that of light,
and then when they return, hundreds of years have passed on the Earth.
That's hard science.
Yeah.
Many writers, if they're considered hard science or soft science,
and some mix the two styles together,
what part does hard science play in your writing?
Well, I try to use it to make the worlds that are in an event more beliefful.
At least to me, since I do have a background in science and engineering,
I think—
well, the writer has to at least suspend his own disbelief
while he's making up these stories.
It's easier for me to do it at a fairly solid scientific foundation.
Even though my science is rather old-fashioned
to probably rather sloppy by a real scientist's standards.
It's still enough to convince me,
so it's fulfilled its function.
For instance, it goes deeper than just description,
the time dilation in the forever war.
Though it's scientifically accurate,
its main function is metaphorical.
and that is to demonstrate how the soldiers who fight a war
become isolated from the culture that they're supposed to be protecting.
Just using a science fictional device to exaggerate
something that happens to every soldier.
Yeah, and that when these soldiers leave and come back,
the world they left is in even the same world once they get back to it.
Which is quite true.
I remember when I came back from Vietnam, I was suddenly plunged into what was an alien culture,
even though I'd only been a soldier for two years.
A lot of things had changed.
You know, it's not a great thing to come back.
There were no victory parades and that sort of thing.
Yeah.
I can empathize with that.
Yeah.
The conflicts aside, Forever War and Mind Bridge have optimistic endings.
But in your novel, All My Sins Remembered, was that put together from a series of short stories?
About half of it appeared as two novelettes, you know.
Yeah. But in the end of it, the protagonist is just literally turned off and killed at the end of it.
It's a rather pessimistic ending.
Well, it was planned all along that way.
The story is about a bureaucracy that totally takes over a man's identity,
and he doesn't really exist except as a tool for that bureaucracy.
When he becomes an efficient tool, he's scrapped.
Yeah, he's programmed to go out and do certain,
I guess what you'd call covert operations.
Yeah.
and he does them
more or less against his will
that is to say
through very advanced techniques
of conditioning
he's turned into

he was a Buddhist

yeah finally
man, he was no longer suited their purpose and then they got rid of him.

Uh, uh, jumping up to MIND BBRIDGE, um, it's dedicated to your teachers at the Iowa
Writers Workshop.
Right.
And the style of the novel is unusual.
Is there a connection with that?
Oh, not really.
The connection is with John Dos Paussos, actually.
I read the USA Trilogy some years before I wrote Mind Bridge
and really was impressed by the way it worked
and thought it would work really well in science fiction.
So I tried it out in a rather long short story
to Howard Hughes, A Modest Proposal.
And it looked like it would work,
so I went ahead and applied it to Mind Bridge.
I did do most of that book while I was studying at Iowa,
That's why it's a dedication.
You also used some humor to Howard Hughes' Amada's proposal.
Do you find that a useful tool to get across your message?
Yeah.
Sarcasm is the operative word.
I think even in a deadly serious book there has to be some leavening of humor.
A lot of science fiction is just too somber and full of message.
I think my primary function is to be an entertainer.
Humor is part of that.
I also noticed in the dedication, a lot of the authors at the workshop were mainstream authors.
What was their reaction to science fiction?
Well, they were a little apprehensive about it.
See, they didn't know I was a science fiction writer when I joined the workshop.
So I joined on the basis of my first novel, which was not science fiction.
And some of them were outwardly hostile towards science fiction, such as Stanley Elkham.
Others were anywhere between apprehensive and slightly sympathetic.
Yeah.
Yeah.
But they couldn't ignore the fact that I was making more money than most of them were with my science fiction.
and that might have been
a cause of tension
in some cases.
Yeah, that's a point
that's kind of hard to argue with.
Yeah.
Yeah, that attitude
is one I've never really
been able to understand
because some of our
greatest novels
are science fiction novels.
Well, that's true.
But the field is judged
by its worst,
not by its best.
And people like that
think of science fiction,
they think in terms
of grade B movies
and lousy television.
They have never read much of that best of the field.
It's a pity.
That's true.
Back again to the Mine Bridge,
a specific question about it.
The alien race that created the Mine Bridge,
you suggest they commit racial suicide.
Why do you think a supposedly advanced race
would do something like that?
I don't know.
I was feeling,
well, they've lived for millions or hundreds of millions
or even billions of years thoroughly, individually immortal,
and there just wasn't anything else that they hadn't done, except died.
But that's sort of a throw away.
I didn't put any deep thought into why they should do that.
I just wanted the image of the light from their passing, lighting up the Knights of the Earth while humans were just meandered gone.
They supernova-ed this star.
The Cygnus loop is the remains of the civilization.
Yeah. I may be wrong here in this next question so correct me if I am. In Tri-Centennial,
when the starship returns to Earth all of the humans are gone, Yeah, it never returns
actually. It doesn't return, okay. That is a shift in view point. Oh, okay, what happened
to the humans on the Earth? Some sort of a war, I assume. Okay. The um, it doesn't say
anything except that there's no life left on Earth and it looks pretty much like an ecological zero, it's just a void
And my other question about Trostantino is who were the beings in the glass and metal tubes?
Oh, those are the leftovers, the people who were on the L5 type colony, they're still there
Their society is a closed-cycle agriculture society,
and there's no reason that they would have to die when the earth died.
Uh-huh, okay.
Yeah.
In various novels and stories that you've written,
you've created some excellent aliens.
How do you go about constructing your aliens?
Not very logically.
I've been asked that before, and it's a hard thing to answer.
I know, for instance, the LeVrye in Mind Bridge.
I did have this notion of aliens who were shape changers,
who appeared as angelically beautiful creatures,
but were ferocious killers, mindless killers.
I wanted that image.
But normally, I don't know the Sikang and All My Sons Remembered.
I just thought I'd make a big bug that had a Jewish sense of humor.
Everything else is decoration.
You sort of close your eyes and see this critter and type it down.
I have on occasion looked through books of animal anatomy
and just glanced through biology and botany textbooks
to try to be inspired by natural forms, but I don't have any algorithm
that I know works for making monsters.
In MindBridge and Forever War, humanity has greatly changed
at the end of both books, almost an evolutionary difference.

That was an odd thing, I had to sign a two-bump contract.

And the first one took three months, and the second took nine.

Um, uh, as to your writing itself,
How do you go about constructing your novels? Do you come up with an idea for the novel
or characters and then work them into a particular setting or what?
Well, the most consistent pattern they have is working out the actual structure,
the way time is handled in the novel. It sounds rather dry, but I don't like to outline the story
in any detail because then there are no surprises.
So I start out with the structure,
how the viewpoint is handled and so forth,
and start working and modify the structure
as the story builds.
Usually I have some vague idea of how it's going to end
that becomes less vague as the novel progresses.
In short stories I normally start with a character
who seems interesting and make him do something.
... in other words you set up sort of a lettuce work and then you let the story build itself on that.
Yeah. That seems to work better for me.
Although often the structure does have to be modified
halfway through. I don't you know want to fit into a Procrastean bed by it.
Yeah, um, Okay.

Yeah, so far I have.
The reason for doing it is to maintain a high level of critical attention for the books.
These books that are sold as paperback originals don't get reviewed in the right places.
Because you do get more money up front, of course, doing a paperback deal.
But it seems to have worked in my case to go with the traditional route.
Yeah.
